qas.question: Chopin was noted as introducing music to what?
What year did Schumann review Chopin's piano concertos?
In his review Schumann made note of Chopin's emotions for what?
Why did Schumann say the Poles were in mourning?
A biography on Chopin released under Franz Liszt's name was likely written by who?
Chopin was able to bring about a new sense of nationalism with his music because of his mazurkas and what?
Who wrote a glowing review of Chopin's love for his country through his music in 1836?
Schumann described Chopin's music as cannons buried in what?
Though Franz Liszt is credited with Chopin's 1863 biography, who probably actually wrote it?

context: With his mazurkas and <a5_0>polonaises<a5_0/>, Chopin has been credited with introducing to music a new <a0_0>sense of nationalism<a0_0/>. <a6_0>Schumann<a6_0/>, in his <a1_0>1836<a1_0/> review of the piano concertos, highlighted the composer's strong feelings for his native <a2_0>Poland<a2_0/>, writing that "Now that the Poles are in deep mourning [after <a3_0>the failure of the November 1830<a3_0/> rising], their appeal to us artists is even stronger ... If the mighty autocrat in the north [i.e. Nicholas I of Russia] could know that in Chopin's works, in the simple strains of his mazurkas, there lurks a dangerous enemy, he would place a ban on his music. Chopin's works are cannon buried in <a7_0>flowers<a7_0/>!" The biography of Chopin published in 1863 under the name of Franz Liszt (but probably written by <a4_0><a8_0>Carolyne zu Sayn-Wittgenstein<a8_0/><a4_0/>) claims that Chopin "must be ranked first among the first musicians ... individualizing in themselves the poetic sense of an entire nation."
